original_data.question:
A 75-year-old man presents to the physician for his annual blood pressure visit and blood work. He has no complaints other than occasional knee pain. The past medical history includes hypertension. He has had knee osteoarthritis for several years and takes occasional acetaminophen for pain control. His diet is full of vegetables. He exercises every day. He has no history of smoking. He had a brother who died at the age of 84 due to hematologic malignancy. The temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉), and the blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The physical examination shows no abnormalities other than a reduced range of motion and crepitus in both knees. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 58,000/mm3
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Flow cytometry on the peripheral blood reveals an absolute lymphocyte count of 50,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a clonal disorder of B lymphocytes. The peripheral blood contains increased numbers of mature-appearing lymphocytes. Flow cytometry confirms the B cell nature of the process by demonstrating the typical pan-B cell markers CD19 and CD20. CD5 and CD23 are also positive in CLL, but these are not specific. The absence of myeloperoxidase or lysozyme activity excludes a leukemoid reaction or a myeloid disorder. The lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by predominantly small lymphocytes with condensed chromatin, and scanty cytoplasm. The bone marrow is usually diffusely involved, and shows a pattern similar to that seen in the peripheral blood. The clinical course of CLL is variable. Many patients are asymptomatic at diagnosis, but the course is typically progressive. The median survival is 7-8 years following diagnosis, but much longer symptom-free survivals are quite common. The diagnosis of monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis (MBL) is made when a patient has a persistent (>6 months) absolute lymphocyte count greater than 5,000/mm3, and a clonal lymphocyte population is detected by flow cytometry. MBL is an asymptomatic condition that may progress to CLL or another lymphoid disorder such as Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia or lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. The diagnosis of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) requires a serum monoclonal protein concentration less than 3 g/dL, and less than 10% plasma cells in the bone marrow. MGUS is an asymptomatic condition that may progress to multiple myeloma (MM). MM is characterized by a serum monoclonal protein concentration greater than 3 g/dL, and bone marrow plasma cells greater than 10%. The clinical course of MM is highly variable. The median survival is 5 years with appropriate therapy. The diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) requires a sustained absolute lymphocyte count greater than 5,000/mm3, and a clonal lymphocyte population detected by flow cytometry. CLL is an asymptomatic condition that may progress to lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and bone marrow failure.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Occurring or done each year.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
The body fluid that circulates in the vascular system (BLOOD VESSELS). Whole blood includes PLASMA and BLOOD CELLS.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.

Noninflammatory degenerative disease of the knee joint consisting of three large categories: conditions that block normal synchronous movement, conditions that produce abnormal pathways of motion, and conditions that cause stress concentration resulting in changes to articular cartilage. (Crenshaw, Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 8th ed, p2019)
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
Analgesic antipyretic derivative of acetanilide. It has weak anti-inflammatory properties and is used as a common analgesic, but may cause liver, blood cell, and kidney damage.
A form of therapy that employs a coordinated and interdisciplinary approach for easing the suffering and improving the quality of life of those experiencing pain.
Regular course of eating and drinking adopted by a person or animal.
A food group comprised of EDIBLE PLANTS or their parts.

Physical activity which is usually regular and done with the intention of improving or maintaining PHYSICAL FITNESS or HEALTH. Contrast with PHYSICAL EXERTION which is concerned largely with the physiologic and metabolic response to energy expenditure.
Occurring or done each day.
Willful or deliberate act of inhaling and exhaling SMOKE from burning substances or agents held by hand.
A male sibling.
Irreversible cessation of all bodily functions, manifested by absence of spontaneous breathing and total loss of cardiovascular and cerebral functions.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.

Neoplasms located in the blood and blood-forming tissue (the bone marrow and lymphatic tissue). The commonest forms are the various types of LEUKEMIA, of LYMPHOMA, and of the progressive, life-threatening forms of the MYELODYSPLASTIC SYNDROMES.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Air trapped in the subcutaneous space. It can be palpated or heard as a crackling or grating sensation under the skin.
A region of the lower extremity immediately surrounding and including the KNEE JOINT.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Technique using an instrument system for making, processing, and displaying one or more measurements on individual cells obtained from a cell suspension. Cells are usually stained with one or more fluorescent dyes specific to cell components of interest, e.g., DNA, and fluorescence of each cell is measured as it rapidly transverses the excitation beam (laser or mercury arc lamp). Fluorescence provides a quantitative measure of various biochemical and biophysical properties of the cell, as well as a basis for cell sorting. Other measurable optical parameters include light absorption and light scattering, the latter being applicable to the measurement of cell size, shape, density, granularity, and stain uptake.

A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.
Complete and without restriction or qualification; something that does not depend on anything else; not relative.

White blood cells formed in the body's lymphoid tissue. The nucleus is round or ovoid with coarse, irregularly clumped chromatin while the cytoplasm is typically pale blue with azurophilic (if any) granules. Most lymphocytes can be classified as either T or B (with subpopulations of each), or NATURAL KILLER CELLS.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
